G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Somerville District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the events giving rise to this claim occurred at Defendant's store located in Somerville, Massachusetts.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners and businesses owe a duty to maintain their premises in a reasonably safe condition for all lawful visitors. (See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1973)).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the seminal Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care toward all lawful visitors. The quoted passage is from a concurrence criticizing the remaining special treatment of trespassers, but the majority at 363 Mass. 693, 708 expressly holds that landowners must act as reasonable persons in maintaining their property for lawful entrants. Thus, while this excerpt does not itself contain the holding, the case as a whole supports the stated proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708 (1.relevant_excerpt: “We hold that the distinction between licensees and invitees is abolished and that the occupier of land owes to all lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care under all of the circumstances.” (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–708 (1973)).

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Massachusetts recognizes a property owner's duty to maintain their premises in a reasonably safe condition to prevent harm to invitees. (See Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973); Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)).
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the duty of one who controls business premises to use due care to keep them in a reasonably safe condition for patrons or to warn them of hidden dangers. Although the case focuses on whether there was sufficient evidence of notice of a foreign substance to go to the jury, it clearly reaffirms the general Massachusetts rule regarding a property owner/occupier’s duty to invitees, which is the proposition cited.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 786 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: The presence of a puddle on the floor in a grocery store constitutes a dangerous condition under Massachusetts premises liability law. (See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 786 (2007)).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion does treat a grape and associated liquid on a supermarket floor as an unsafe or hazardous condition, but its focus is on the mode-of-operation doctrine and notice, not on defining that any puddle or spill is per se a dangerous condition. The quoted page (and the case generally) assumes without extended analysis that such produce debris and liquid create an obvious risk, but it does not establish a broad rule that the mere presence of a puddle in a grocery store constitutes a dangerous condition under Massachusetts premises liability law. Thus, using this case for that categorical proposition is overbroad.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “In particular, as is the case here, fruit and vegetable debris presents an obvious risk of injury to a customer, and a reasonably prudent person would not place these items in an aisle or allow them to remain there. Thus, because the determination of reasonableness is a question of fact, the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee or anticipate that a foreseeable risk stemming from the owner’s mode of operation could occur and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.raw_text: Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc., 346 Mass. 31, 34 (1963)
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.proposition: A property owner or business is liable for injuries caused by a dangerous condition on its premises if the owner had actual or constructive notice of the condition and failed to take reasonable steps to address it. (See Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc., 346 Mass. 31, 34 (1963)).
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.case_name: City Bank & Trust Co. v. Board of Bank Incorporation
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns judicial review of a banking regulator’s denial of an application to open a branch office and the interpretation of statutory language regarding administrative hearings. It does not address premises liability, dangerous conditions on property, or notice of such conditions. The proposition about a property or business owner’s liability for injuries on premises is unrelated to the issues decided in this case, so the citation is inaccurate for that proposition.
Sarkisian v. Concept Restaurants, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: Nor is it to be readily assumed that the Legislature intended that a board consisting of one State constitutional officer and two commissioners of departments should be subordinated to the courts in its determination of this sort of question. What was said in the Natick Trust Co. case, supra, 617, is still true: ‘This was a political question, one of governmental policy peculiarly for the determination of an administrative department.’

Giggey v. Century 21, Inc., 451 Mass. 10.proposition: In Massachusetts, an employee's actual knowledge of a dangerous condition is imputed to the employer, making the employer liable for failing to remedy the hazard. (See Restatement (Second) of Agency § 272 (1958); Giggey v. Century 21, Inc., 451 Mass. 1007 (2008)).
Giggey v. Century 21, Inc., 451 Mass. 10.support_reasoning: The opinion in Giggey v. Century 21, Inc., as reproduced here, concerns appellate procedure and the consequences of electing to proceed in small claims, not employer liability or imputation of an employee’s knowledge of a dangerous condition. It does not discuss the Restatement (Second) of Agency § 272, workplace hazards, or any principle about imputing an employee’s knowledge to the employer. Thus, this case, at least in this excerpt, does not support the stated proposition.
Giggey v. Century 21, Inc., 451 Mass. 10.relevant_excerpt: By choosing to pursue his claim as a plaintiff in the small claims session, the petitioner waived his right to appeal from any adverse ruling. See G. L. c. 218, § 23; Pandey v. Ware Div. of the Dist. Court Dep’t, 412 Mass. 1002, 1003 (1992); Fijal v. Anderson, 49 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (2000). Moreover, he fails to substantiate his claim of judicial bias.

Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (.proposition: Defendant's failure to act despite actual knowledge of the spill constitutes a breach of its duty to address known hazards in a timely manner. (See Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988)).
Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address any duty by a defendant to timely clean up or respond to a spill or similar transient hazard. The YWCA portion concerns whether a landowner had duties to investigate a tenant’s competence or to warn of obvious risks created by others; the Mandell portion concerns workers’ compensation obligations. There is no discussion of a failure to act after actual knowledge of a spill or of a duty to remediate such a condition, so the case does not support the cited proposition.
Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (.relevant_excerpt: “A property owner has a duty to use reasonable care to maintain its property in a reasonably safe condition. … The condition that caused Thorson’s injury was not created by the YWCA. That condition was created by Mandell and other people participating in the rehearsal. The risk was inherent in the dance step attempted and obvious to the participants. … [T]he YWCA had no duty to warn against obvious risks.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).proposition: Defendant's negligence caused foreseeable harm to Plaintiff, satisfying the required elements for a negligence claim under Massachusetts law. (See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006)).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).support_reasoning: The cited portion of Jupin v. Kask addresses the elements and existence of a *duty of reasonable care* under Massachusetts negligence law and the role of foreseeability in establishing that duty. It does not hold that “Defendant's negligence caused foreseeable harm to Plaintiff” or that all required negligence elements, including breach and causation, were satisfied; instead, the court only finds a duty and reverses summary judgment so a jury can decide breach and causation. Thus, using this case for the proposition that all elements of negligence were met is inaccurate.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner … has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access… We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”
